review: Purchased for the folks for Netflix and Amazon Prime, which work like a charm.  Also utilizing with Plex Media Server for the home's media.  For the most part, Plex runs great but one can definitely notice a difference in quality.  Also, be aware that not all USB ports on televisions are created equal and the need to always keep the A/C adapter plugged in may be necessary (it comes with said adapter).  The device won't quite buffer as much as its bigger brothers, but unless you're watching an exceptionally long movie, you shouldn't notice.  As a counter point, that could possibly have to do with the horsepower of the computer running the PMS.  However, the Roku 2 doesn't struggle with movies and 3D.

review: We have a Samsung smart TV, a Sony Blu Ray with apps, and now the Roku Stick for streaming. The Samsung TV apps often will not function, probably due to their servers being overloaded. Switching to Sony clears up the problem, so we know it's not the sources (Netflix, Hulu, etc.). We purchased the Roku to get access to Acorn TV and it does provide access, but it seems to have a number of bugs that make it inconvenient to use.1) The resume button doesn't always resume from where it stopped. Sometimes it takes you back to the beginning2) In the middle of playback, the player will "reset" and put us back to the menu.3) Most of these problems have occurred on Acorn, I don't know it's because of a problem with Acorn or Roku.
